replies.body:
Bans are simply a bandaid to the real problem.  They don't fix crap.  There are two fixes that would solve either problem.  Just unlock all champs in ARAM or make some balances for ARAM only, which Rito did dabble at.  Obviously they were successful with the first go around, because no champ has 70% win rates in ARAM anymore.  Currently there is only one that is even above 60%.  There used to be three all near 70% (Sona, Ziggs, Sion).

I think they should just keep small tweaking until more champs are under control and then there is no point to ARAM accounts, unless it is only based on personal preferences of who you want to play.

I think I have only 3 champs left to get, so no, I am not in support of ARAM accounts, but there are better fixes than killing ARAM with bans.  Keep ARAM random (the rerolls are already bad enough)!

"still getting" does not mean "almost certain" , it's actually best for RNG when there is some sort of way to balance it.  So now imagine the players right now who have only champions picked for ARAM, how much does that influence it?  there are, if I remember right, 24 free champs at a time.  Let's say you have 8 mages.  you now have a 1 in 4 chance of drawing a preferred pick.  if it's 16, that number goes to 2/5 , 24 and you now have a 50% chance of rolling the champion you want

with 2 rerolls and the champion pool, this number goes up very quickly

now compare that to rolling with all unlocked for a mage (roughly 40 out of 144) and the odds are at a constant 5/18 or roughly 1/3rd

pretty much the only argument "against" the free champs is "I don't want to play that champ" and yet, neither does anyone who has a large champion pool want to play someone that they rarely play, especially if it's at a huge disadvantage to the other team
I don't. Speak for yourself.

in the end it just removed some of the most enjoyable champs on the map. Sure most people here on the boards complain about champs like lux, but even without aram they do that shit.

Bans solved FUN in ARAM by allowing people to individually remove one thing that made ARAM not fun for them.

If you don't mind lux that much... then don't ban her. *shrugs* I don't mind lux either. I, personally, mind Pyke. Both on my team and the enemy team. So I would usually ban Pyke. It didn't matter if Pyke was strong or not, he wasn't fun to play with or against for me, so I'd remove him from that being an option. If someone banned Pyke, then I'd probably ban Shaco or Teemo, because - again - I don't enjoy having them in the game on either side.

It's not about making ARAM BALANCED. If you want balance, play Ranked. It's about making ARAM fun. Because ARAM is where I used to go to get away from perfectly balanced, stressful competition.

> [{quoted}](name=Teh Song,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=sHjbwHgA,comment-id=000200030000,timestamp=2019-07-05T12:14:06.598+0000)
>
> You can't have fair with random.

That's bullshit. You *can* have fair with random, it's just achieved differently. Fundamentally, the idea of "fair" is to treat everyone equally, to give them an equal opportunity to succeed, and to achieve that in ARAM Riot needs only to open up the full champion roster, thus putting everyone on equal footing, but the fact they continue to allow ARAM accounts to exist unchallenged just means that the idea of "fair" isn't going to apply here, even though it very easily *can*. At the very least, bans would give us, the players, a chance to bring more fairness to that system.

When one team gets 5 Sorakas and the other team gets 5 Dravens, there's nothing fair about that match. Yes I know you can't literally get duplicates but you get the idea.
Sure, you can argue along the lines of "both teams could have been on either side of that" to state the premise that the mode is fair, but that doesn't make that match fair.
I play ARAM because random is fun, which is why I do support opening up the roster to increase the random, but I never expecting it to feel at all fair when I enter that queue.
Although tbh I hate when I get a free week champion instead of one I own, but that's a mental thing of "but I can't get the mastery chest on this person :(" lol

> [{quoted}](name=Teh Song,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=sHjbwHgA,comment-id=00020003000000000000,timestamp=2019-07-05T22:54:31.079+0000)

> When one team gets 5 Sorakas and the other team gets 5 Dravens, *there's nothing fair about that match*.

Again, you're completely missing the fucking point. "Fair" happens when everyone gets the same *opportunity* for success, not necessarily the same *outcome* (it's essentially the difference between "equality" and "equity"). So long as everyone is getting the same *opportunity* for success (in this case, being the *same* random chance of getting any given champion) then it *is* fair, and the fact that things can differ beyond that doesn't change the fundamental fairness of the situation.

> [{quoted}](name=HeartVine,realm=OCE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=sHjbwHgA,comment-id=000200030000000000000000,timestamp=2019-07-06T02:00:22.248+0000)

If you're going to quote me, quote me fully, not just the one sentence you want.

As I said in what you cut out of the quote, it can be argued that it makes the *mode* fair.
It does not make the match fair.
Within a singular match, the concept of fairness begins *after* the champions are assigned, not before.
Within a singular match, the premise of whether or not each team had the same opportunity for success begins *after* the champions are assigned, not before. The question, in a match, is not if everyone had the same opportunity to get the champs, but how effective in an all mid situation the champs they got are.

Notions like ARAM accounts and opening up the roster affect the fairness of the overall mode, but not the fairness of any given match.
I do support opening up the roster, for the record, as much as I dislike playing champions I don't own (though that's just because I like to think I might earn a mastery chest). Even with that done, though, most matches in and of themselves will still be unfair matches. Which is ok, because its a result of the "all random" component, which is the point of the mode.

Except there is no issue. You're really going to cry about accounts who have a small number of champs to play ARAM? There's not a single champion who is going to result in an ARAM win every single time. The highest winrate champ in ARAM is Illaoi at 61.5% (4.6% pick rate because people who have no clue just reroll her, the very same types of people who want bans in ARAM) -- guess who I always see people complaining about in regards to ARAM and wanting a ban feature? Veigar, who has a 52% winrate in ARAM. Blitz is 51%, yet is very commonly mentioned.

You claim that there is an issue. Your claims would also mean this issue is universal, due to the scope of said "issue". How in the hell could you argue that someone doesn't hold value in your claims simply due to them not affecting that person? Either the issue exists or it doesn't. If someone plays a single game of ARAM, with the "issue" you're claiming, they'd inherently have been affected. That, or, the issue is a construct straight from the minds of those who can't stand a loss even in a mode where champions are 100% random. Claiming that there's an issue which is breaking ARAM, then conveniently claiming that a person is opposed only because it doesn't affect them, is hypocrisy and selective logic.

You're going to lose ARAMs. Get over it. You can't win them all, and losing isn't always about some external faceless force bringing you down. Everyone who plays ARAM faces the exact same "issue" you're alleging exists. If you were _truly_ concerned by the "issue" you're creating, you'd also have considered the fact that you're just as likely to get an "ARAM account" on your team as your opponents are. You're simply finding absolutely anything which you can attribute your loss to, and making a big deal out of it. If they permanently reintroduced bans in ARAM, there would be another thread about some other "flaw"/"issue" responsible for your losses.

Bans won't rid you of the possibility of getting a highly counterable team like 100% AP, won't prevent you from getting all melee while the enemy has incredible mobility/range/cc, won't prevent you from getting the average ARAM player who has no clue how to play 99% of champs, and certainly won't account for your lack of knowledge on every champ in your pool. It's ARAM. FFS.

I'll break it down for you. In SR you pick your champ. There are champs who have a high winrate in some elos, and low winrate in others. Your argument is like saying that you shouldn't be allowed to play a champ in a certain division because it has a high winrate. ARAM is almost exclusively low elo. If bans are ever permanently introduced, you will be back, complaining about the next enigmatic external force bringing you down. That's just how bad players are.
